Text: I will praise You, O LORD, with all my heart; I will tell of all Your wonders.
Context: The opening verse sets the tone for the Psalm, with the speaker committing to wholehearted praise of God and declaring His wonders.

Text: I will be glad and rejoice in You; I will sing praise to Your name, O Most High.
Context: The speaker expresses joy and intent to praise, reflecting a personal, emotional response to God's character and deeds.

Text: When my enemies turn back, they stumble and perish before You.
Context: The speaker gives thanks for deliverance from enemies, acknowledging God's role in their defeat.

Text: For You have upheld my cause and my right; You have sat on Your throne judging righteously.
Context: The speaker recognizes God's justice and His support in the speaker's personal cause, implying a legal or moral vindication.

Text: You have rebuked the nations; You have destroyed the wicked; You have erased their name forever and ever.
Context: The speaker describes God's fierce judgment on the nations and the wicked, which results in total obliteration.

Text: The enemy has come to eternal ruin; the cities You have uprooted will be remembered no more.
Context: A matter-of-fact statement about the consequences of God's judgment, suggesting the finality and completeness of the enemy's defeat.

Text: But the LORD abides forever; He has established His throne for judgment.
Context: Contrasts the transient nature of the wicked with the eternal nature of God and His rule.

Text: He will judge the world in righteousness; He will govern the peoples with justice.
Context: Describes God's future judgment, emphasizing its righteous and just nature, which can be comforting for the righteous and terrifying for the wicked.

Text: The LORD is a refuge for the oppressed, a stronghold in times of trouble.
Context: Acknowledges God as a protector and source of security for those facing hardship or injustice.

Text: Those who know Your name trust in You, for You, LORD, have never forsaken those who seek You.
Context: Expresses confidence and hope in God's faithfulness and His attention to those who reach out to Him.

Text: Sing praises to the LORD, who dwells in Zion; declare among the peoples His deeds.
Context: Calls for worship and for spreading the news of God's actions to others.

Text: For the avenger of blood remembers the afflicted; He does not forget the cry of the distressed.
Context: The speaker notes God's memory and attention to injustice, implying that God is moved by the suffering of victims and will act on their behalf.

Text: Be merciful to me, O LORD; see how my enemies afflict me! Lift me up from the gates of death,
Context: The speaker pleads for mercy, expressing belief in God's power to save even from the brink of death.

Text: that I may declare Your praises in the gates of the Daughter of Zion and there rejoice in Your salvation.
Context: The speaker desires rescue so that they can continue to praise and celebrate God's salvation in the community.

Text: The nations have sunk into the pit they have made; their feet are caught in the net they have hidden.
Context: Depicts the downfall of nations as a direct result of their own machinations, suggesting a form of divine justice where evil plans backfire.

Text: The LORD is known by the justice He brings; the wicked are ensnared by the work of their hands.
Context: Higgaion. Selah
column7: A reflective pause (Higgaion. Selah) to consider God's reputation for justice and the irony of the wicked being caught in their own schemes.

Text: The wicked will return to Sheol—all the nations who forget God.
Context: A stark warning that those who forget or ignore God will face death and the grave (Sheol), representing separation from God’s life-giving presence.

Text: For the needy will not always be forgotten; the hope of the afflicted will not perish forever.
Context: Offers assurance that God remembers the marginalized and that their hope for justice is not in vain.

Text: Rise up, O LORD; do not let man prevail; let the nations be judged in Your presence.
Context: The speaker calls on God to act and not allow humanity to succeed in its rebellion against divine authority.

Text: Put terror in them, O LORD; let the nations know they are but men.
Context: Selah
column7: A reflective pause (Selah) to consider the speaker's request for God to instill a sobering realization of human mortality and frailty in the hearts of the nations.
